projectSummary:
I worked on Event Connect as a 20% project at Google in the capacity of a designer, prototyper, and front-end engineer. Event Connect is an application designed to coordinate the creation and logistics associated with both internal and external events at Google such as academic conferences and university visits.

In the course of my time working with the EC team I helped launch major redesigns of large portions of the application’s primary functionality which directly lead to large gains in the overall usability and navigation of Event Connect.

I helped design, build, and deploy an analytics dashboard focused on measuring the productivity and overall quality of the actions taken by a globally distributed operations team whose purpose was to prevent fraudulent transactions from occurring on Google’s payments platform.

My role on this project was unique in that I built an end-to-end reporting platform which provided unique and customizable views and reports based on the viewers job function. The dashboard furthermore reduced the metrics generation process previously followed by front-line managers by over 75%.

While at Liberty Mutual I worked closely with our consumer user-experience team on a variety of desktop web and mobile projects. Specifically, I was the primary prototyper for Liberty Mutual’s first mobile website, a redesigned version of the company’s primary site, a redesigned version of their eService customer account management application, and a redesigned insurance office locator.

In my prototyping role I often led and participated in ideation exercises with relevant stakeholders before fleshing out ideas in low and high fidelity prototypes. In many cases I would iterate through paper sketches, move to wireframes, and eventually finish with high-fidelity interactive prototypes that I would pass onto our development team.

I worked in a 20% capacity to develop and iterate upon designs for as yet unreleased component of Google’s Transparency Report.

While I am unable to share anything at this time, I will update this project summary with further details upon the public release of the implementation of my designs.

I designed and built an end-to-end native Android application that calculates a Physical Fitness Test (PFT) score for the United States Marine Corps. Using the inputs of a user’s gender and age coupled with their 3-mile run time, 2 minute sit-up count, and maximum pull-up count, USMC ProFitness allows users to calculate and track their fitness scores over time.

I built USMC ProFitness over several weekends after setting a new years resolution for myself to start developing with Android.

I was selected as a member of the first 100 internal trusted testers to begin using Google Glass in December of 2012. In this testing capacity I provided feedback in the form of weekly surveys and participated in a number of user research studies surrounding general use and new features.

I am currently working on undisclosed research projects involving Glass at the University of Washington with Eve Riskin.

While working at Google, I pursued a coursework in the school of Web Design & New Media at the Academy of Art University.

The coursework I completed focused on the fundamentals of visual design, the Adobe Creative Suite, and communication through sketching. Select assignments from my coursework are highlighted in my portfolio.

While working as a member of Liberty Mutual’s user experience team I under a project to examine, consolidate, and improve the disparate RSS feeds found across Liberty’s multiple web properties. I used as a basis for my improvements both industry best practices and a detailed competitive analysis of RSS as used by other leading insurance companies.

This project upon its eventual implementation led to improved customer messaging, a reduction in duplicated messaging, increased relevancy, and a 25% increase in new RSS subscriptions.

projectName: Website Design for Law Offices of Marie Higuera
projectSummary:
In the Fall of 2011 I was contracted by Marie Higuera to redesign the website associated with her law practice. I transferred their previous domain name to a new hosting provider and implemented a HTML5 based website in place of their previous static site. The redesigned version was fully cross-browser compatible on all modern webkit based browsers and gracefully degrades backward to IE7.

I did some light graphics work for this project in Adobe Fireworks and implemented a jquery based image slider on the homepage. The entire project took roughly a month of part-time work to design and implement. The final result was significantly increased traffic to the firm's website and an improved user experience.

In the Fall of 2010 I helped lead an effort to consolidate the sitemap an hierarchy of information across Liberty Mutual’s public websites. The study broke apart 50 site link’s into individual cards and asked participants to group and categorize the cards together by themselves before breaking into groups and repeating the exercise together.

The study took place over the course of several weeks after which my UX team spent several additional weeks quantifying our data with the methodology outlined in Donna Spencer's book ‘Card Sorting Designing Usable Categories’. The eventual outcome of the project consolidated Liberty Mutual's sitemap from 18 base categories into 6 and provided a foundation from which we were able to design a reimagined mega-menu.

I spent several months on a rotational program at Liberty Mutual helping to design and build the company’s first mobile-web, android, and iOS applications.

While working on the mobile development team I was primarily responsible for the interaction design of each application the team was building. I additionally produced wireframes, interactive prototypes, and helped to plan and conduct usability studies for our iOS application.

I worked with two small business owners in the summer of 2008 to construct an online presence and ecommerce solution for a now defunct organic clothing company based in Buffalo, NY. I deployed a website and custom template built on osCommerce. Additionally I was responsible for both Authorize.Net and PayPal integrations.

The site was deployed on a Linux Apache server and utilized both mySQL and PHP. The resulting work from my internship was an aesthetically clean ecommerce solution that allowed Buffalo GreenArt to expand their user-base and engage in new ways with their current customers.
